H.R. 119- The National Statistics on Deadly Force Transparency Act of 2019 is a bill led by @RepCohen that requires law enforcement agencies at the federal, state, and local level to compile & submit data on the use of deadly force to the DOJ.
 
Bill text:
https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/119/text

H.R. 125- The Police Training and Independent Review Act of 2019 is a bill led by @RepCohen that uses federal $ to incentivize police departments to require sensitivity training, conduct independent investigations & prosecute incidents of excessive force.

https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/125/text

H.R. 1636- The Commission on the Social Status of Black Men and Boys Act of 2019 is a proposal from @RepWilson that would create a bipartisan commission to study societal challenges that affect Black males & recommend solutions.
 
Bill text:
https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/1636/text

H.R. 4408- The Eric Garner Excessive Use of Force Prevention Act of 2019 was introduced by @RepJeffries. It bars the use of chokeholds by law enforcement officers & amends/clarifies existing law to make the practice a criminal offense.

Bill text:

As we kick off #PrideMonth, we celebrate the progress made towards equality and honor the brave voices who helped create change. Our country faces more work ahead to protect the most marginalized in our continued fight for fairness and equality.

There is no one answer to the pain & anguish our country feels right now. But police militarization must be addressed. 

I'm a cosponsor of the Stop Militarizing Law Enforcement Act & I strongly support legislation to stop police militarization.
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/01/us/politics/police-military-gear.html?smid=fb-nytimes&smtyp=cur&fbclid=IwAR29syY9Ik8vMYwkzJthO1heCvlb_eRP4mEu1f5jl_OttIDFbS_uag8WkS0

President Obama initiated a number of reforms to ensure that military assault equipment didn't end up getting used against American citizens.

President Trump, to bipartisan opposition, reversed those reforms in 2017.
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/28/us/politics/trump-police-military-surplus-equipment.html

To be clear, some of the equipment transfers are fine. Excess office furniture, first aid kits, commercial vehicles.

But why would our police departments need grenade launchers, bayonets, and armored assault vehicles?

These are weapons of war that have no place on our streets.

Let's talk police militarization.

Right now, there's a pentagon program that transfers excess military equipment to local law enforcement.

I think that's a terrible idea. In fact, I'm one of only a handful of House members who voted against it last time it came up for a vote.

Our work is not over until that is true, until we eradicate the fundamental problems and prejudice that allows for these miscarriages of justice to happen in the first place.
12/

It is well past time for the leaders of our country to act and make policy changes to combat discrimination against marginalized communities.

The color of your skin should not dictate your quality of education, housing, health care, or safety. 
11/

Law enforcement is a dangerous profession and although most police officers honor their oath to protect and serve their communities, we cannot continue to ignore the abuse of power and discrimination against people of color by those that do not. 
10/

I promise to continue to do more and do better, to listen and learn from Black and Brown community leaders and constituents I am honored to serve.

I will work together with members of our community, elected officials, and anyone who is willing to stand on the side of justice.
9/

How can we end the disparities in housing, health care, education, and justice for communities of color?

How can we break down systemic racism once and for all?

These questions demand thoughtful answers with real solutions. We have the responsibility to act.
8/

I‚Äôve joined peaceful protests, spoken with community leaders, and engaged with law enforcement searching for answers to the questions: 

How can we stop this from happening again and again?

How can we hold bad actors accountable?  
7/

The response should not be more violence as violence begets violence & perpetuates hate, division, & injustice. 

It is my responsibility - and that of all our leaders - to listen & learn & commit to working together to bring accountability, justice, & ultimately, change. 
6/

George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor, and those before them deserve accountability and justice above all.

We must stay focused on finding solutions to the very real problems caused by racial discrimination, while also being respectful to our fellow Americans.
5/

Unfortunately, in some places we‚Äôve seen this pain co-opted by looters & people who seek to divide & distract us.

Violence & looting are not acts of political expression, they‚Äôre criminal. We cannot allow violence by few to take away from those who seek to make real change.
4/

In America, the right to peacefully protest is an inalienable one, which must be protected by all elected leaders no matter what. I hope the messages being shared in recent days by people of color about the effects of systemic & institutionalized racism will be met w/ action.
3/

That pain has poured out into the streets with peaceful demonstrations across the world and right here in our communities. 

I support the countless Americans participating in these peaceful demonstrations.
2/

Like so many Americans, my heart is breaking. I know I will never fully understand the pain Black Americans are feeling.

The murder of George Floyd at the hands of someone who is sworn to protect him is reprehensible, & has happened to too many Black Americans in our country.
1/

As Texas continues to reopen and we look forward to a full economic reopening, I‚Äôm excited for President Donald Trump to sign this legislation to get small businesses the relief they so badly need. Let‚Äôs get it done.

My bill will help our businesses stay afloat. It will help those that have been left on the outside looking in on the loan process. It will help make sure our workers have jobs to return to on the other side. It will help communities across Central Texas bridge the gap.

Last week, the Paycheck Protection Flexibility Act passed the House overwhelmingly 417-1. I was thrilled to see the bill pass the Senate this evening.  I‚Äôd like to thank my colleagues in the House and Senate for working together to take swift, decisive action.
...to get it done. Our hard work started gaining traction immediately. It won the support of a diverse coalition of in excess of 50 outside groups, as well as bipartisan support.

We didn‚Äôt have much time to waste. I got started right away.

My staff and I began drafting legislation to ease up loan requirements and eliminate onerous restrictions to allow more businesses to obtain relief. We teamed up with my colleague, @RepDeanPhillips,...

I knew that Congress had to act quickly to provide flexibility to account for different business structures and operating expenses to make the program work. We were already watching our communities lose some of our favorite restaurants, shops, hotels, and Central Texas haunts.

From my conversations, as well as numerous visits with business owners, employees, and members of our #TX21 community, it became clear that changes were necessary to make the program work for many businesses.
For months, I‚Äôve heard from small business owners in Central Texas who have, for one reason or another, been unable to take loans provided under the Paycheck Protection Program.

Thank you, @IvankaTrump.
